utterance: XS: Yeah, no, it's okay. It's, it's good. Uh, yes, I'm Xiao. I am in chemical engineering, the University of Illinois, Urbana Champaign. So I joined last year in 2019. So molecules look very similar and I think that that can go beyond the carbon dioxide space, which is I guess related to the topic.

utterance: LS: Dual zooming during our break yesterday, and we had a seminar speaker from Johnson Matthew. They're talking about even for hydrogen. But as a mechanism for hydrogen storage, there is a significant push actually to convert electrochemically produced hydrogen, thermally convert it to ammonia for more easy transportation, and then thermal catalytically convert it back to hydrogen for the use. Now, there can be arguments can be made about whether that's useful or whether you would just want to use the ammonia once you've had it. But I'm kind of then looking at the economics of that sort of a process. Is it worth also an electro investigating an electrochemical route to ammonia production if this thermal route is is really so efficient that you can go back and forth simply as a means for more facile transportation even at scale.

annotations.present new idea: The speaker introduces the idea of converting electrochemically produced hydrogen to ammonia for easier transportation and then back to hydrogen, which is a novel concept in the context of the discussion.
annotations.expand on existing idea: The speaker expands on the idea of hydrogen storage by discussing the thermal conversion of hydrogen to ammonia and back, adding details about its potential use and efficiency.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: The speaker supports the idea by mentioning a seminar speaker from Johnson Matthew who discussed this approach for hydrogen storage, providing an external source as evidence.
annotations.ask clarifying question: The speaker poses a question about the economic viability of an electrochemical route to ammonia production compared to the thermal route, seeking clarification on its worth.

utterance: AT: I would also add the argument of the localized production of ammonia. Those numbers that you just cited benefit hugely from the economy of scale and being able to have these energy recovery for the thermal recovery especially. So if you want to have a distributed network where nitrogen is obviously a distributed resource. Can you capitalize on that with such efficiencies?

annotations.expand on existing idea: AT is building on the previous discussion about hydrogen storage and transportation by adding the argument of localized ammonia production, which contrasts with the economy of scale benefits mentioned earlier.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: AT refers to 'those numbers that you just cited' to support the argument that the benefits of thermal recovery are dependent on the economy of scale.
annotations.present new idea: AT introduces the idea of a distributed network for ammonia production, capitalizing on nitrogen as a distributed resource, which is a new concept in the context of the conversation.

utterance: HW: I can add something here for of course for the energy input from renewable electricity to reduce nitrogen to ammonia is a very attractive route. But still starting from how to say maybe 20 10 years ago, there is a big wave coming in doing this nitrogen reduction to ammonia. But the more published papers we see, but there comes out a big problem is the let's say it's like called the false positive signals coming from this result. That concerns a lot, not only my own research, but a lot of my friends inside the field, we have the concerns about how to repeat others results. It's because the current density nowadays we can do under the room temperature to reduce nitrogen is very, very small. It's less than maybe 0.1 milliamp. There is some report is 1 milliamp or even more. But it is really difficult for for people to repeat. This is also another consideration as Marcel has already mentioned the harbor Bosch, maybe, you know, several orders of magnitudes higher energy efficiency than using the electricity to reduce nitrogen to ammonia. Is that possible or it doesn't make sense for us to sacrifice some of the energy efficiencies to convert nitrogen to reduce nitrogen to ammonia or we improve the water splitting efficiency to generate the hydrogen we need and go through the harbor Bosch process to get the ammonia we need. That needs to be debated actually if at least at this current stage. But it's still open discussions like in the future we probably will get a very good catalyst to to add room temperature to reduce nitrogen to ammonia. That's that's also very possible.

annotations.expand on existing idea: HW is building on the discussion about ammonia production by adding information about the challenges and limitations of electrochemical nitrogen reduction to ammonia, which was previously mentioned by DK and AT.

annotations.provide supporting evidence: HW provides supporting evidence by mentioning the issue of false positive signals and the difficulty in replicating results in electrochemical nitrogen reduction, and also compares the energy efficiency of this method to the Haber-Bosch process.

annotations.explain or define term or concept: HW explains the concept of false positive signals in the context of nitrogen reduction research, clarifying a potential issue in the field.

annotations.propose decision: HW proposes a decision by questioning whether it makes sense to sacrifice energy efficiency for electrochemical nitrogen reduction or to improve water splitting efficiency for the Haber-Bosch process.

utterance: XS: I just like to add from a different perspective because I don't work on reactions, but more separations, is that there's a lot of interest I've seen from doing the reaction for nitrogen conversion from nitrates. And I think from a separation perspective, there is a advantage there is because you can recover waste nitrate of concentrated electrochemically and they use it for upcycling. So there's a lot of interesting electrochemical challenges in the nitrogen product and precursor separation that maybe when integrated with the reactions might make the overall system more efficient just because you can have one happening at the cathode, the other at the anode. So you have full integration. But I don't know how that fits into the whole energetics. I think from an electrochemical separation perspective, there's all sorts of sustainability and chemical consumption advantages.

annotations.present new idea: The speaker introduces the idea of nitrogen conversion from nitrates as a reaction of interest.
annotations.expand on existing idea: The speaker builds on the discussion of nitrogen conversion by adding the perspective of electrochemical separations, suggesting that recovering waste nitrate electrochemically and upcycling it could improve overall system efficiency.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: The speaker supports the idea of electrochemical separations by mentioning the sustainability and chemical consumption advantages.

utterance: DK: One thing that's worth thinking about is trying to zoom out a little bit and think about, you know, what's the role of nitrogen in negative emissions? And the role is to sustain enhanced biological production that will draw down extra carbon dioxide. So I think there, you know, there's really good reason to question is that the best route to go, you know, how much carbon dioxide, how much additional carbon dioxide can you capture? What are the co-benefits of doing so? What are the disbenefits, like the extra consumption of say fresh water and nutrients on land? And then also, what's the degree of permanence? Like, you know, I live in California, a lot of our natural carbon a lot of our natural climate solutions just went up in flames in the last few months. And so when we're thinking about this role of nitrogen, um it's probably worth zooming out and thinking about, you know, what's the end fate of that nitrogen?

annotations.present new idea: The speaker introduces the idea of considering the role of nitrogen in negative emissions, which hasn't been explicitly discussed before in the conversation.
annotations.ask clarifying question: The speaker poses several questions about the carbon capture potential, co-benefits, disbenefits, and permanence of nitrogen's role in negative emissions, seeking to clarify the overall impact and sustainability of this approach.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: The speaker supports their questioning of the role of nitrogen by mentioning the recent wildfires in California, highlighting the lack of permanence in natural carbon solutions.

utterance: MS: I would like to add to this. I think another role that actually ammonia can place as an energy carrier. I think it's it's a fairly elegant energy carrier. We can store it. Okay. Ammonia is a bit toxic. That's kind of the problem. On the other end, um we can actually liquefy it at reasonable temperatures, reasonable pressures. So it is a fairly good energy carrier. We can essentially attach hydrogen atoms to nitrogen, shuffle them around and and use them like Lindsay said. I think that's just something that we might also want to kind of keep in in view. It could be a very green, sustainable and thus reduce the carbon generation at least. It's not a carbon negative, so that's it's not a negative emission. It's a neutral emission technology.

annotations.expand on existing idea: MS is building upon the previous discussion about nitrogen and ammonia by adding the idea that ammonia can serve as an energy carrier.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: MS provides supporting evidence for ammonia's potential as an energy carrier by mentioning its ability to be stored, liquefied at reasonable conditions, and used to shuffle hydrogen atoms.
annotations.explain or define term or concept: MS clarifies that using ammonia as an energy carrier is a carbon-neutral emission technology, not a carbon-negative one.

utterance: YL: I want to mention something about the fundamental side of the nitrogen reduction. So as mentioned, there are many experiments about nitrogen reduction to ammonium, which cannot be reproduced by other groups. And that's actually challenging for any needs for computational chemist like me because I try to for example, if I say a paper published for example in nature or science reporting very high performance for the catalytic and to reduction to ammonium. Then I would like to follow up with this experiment trying to understand why this catalyst is so good. What's what is the fundamental mechanism underlying this catalyst? But it turns out after sometime, this paper, I mean, cannot be reproduced. Some people are saying their experiments are not done carefully. So, so if I want to follow those papers, then I would, you know, waste some time trying to study something which is actually not experimentally verified. So I think, uh, yeah, it's very important to get clean experiments, reproducible experiments as a basis for computational studies.

annotations.present new idea: The speaker introduces the idea that irreproducible experimental results in nitrogen reduction pose a challenge for computational chemists who rely on these results for their studies, which is a new perspective in the conversation.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: The speaker supports their claim about the challenges of irreproducible experiments by mentioning that many experiments on nitrogen reduction to ammonium cannot be reproduced by other groups, and that some people are saying their experiments are not done carefully.
annotations.express frustration: The speaker expresses frustration about wasting time studying papers that cannot be reproduced, highlighting the difficulty in relying on experimental results that lack reproducibility.

utterance: CJ: Labeling studies in this area are really important. A lot of the false CO2 reduction and N2 reduction papers in the literature could have been avoided if people did labeling studies.

annotations.explain or define term or concept: The utterance implicitly explains the importance of 'labeling studies' in the context of CO2 and N2 reduction research, highlighting their role in preventing false results.

utterance: MS: I just have I have a kind of almost a kind of fundamental concern. So I first of all, I don't want to discredit research on nitrogen reduction because I think from a scientific perspective, it's fascinating. This nitrogen dinitrogen bond is fascinating. But when you then look at an engineering perspective, when we think about what we need to do to do an electrochemical transformation of nitrogen. Now we just think at scale, right? We need to bring in dinitrogen and we need to bring in protons and we need to bring in current. So we need obviously a kind of triple phase boundary or or kind of a gas diffusion electrode kind of design. This will be very difficult, especially if we're bringing in the gaseous species, which is very weakly soluble. I think that's where people struggle. Whereas if we are generating hydrogen in an electrolyzer, we have no transport problem. We just can bring water to the reaction side with very high transport rates, generate hydrogen, get the gas, and then convert it together with the second gas nitrogen in a in a in a Harbor Bosch process. So I just think when we look at this from this engineering perspective, right? This need for a triple phase boundary compared to the ease of generating hydrogen electrochemically, we may kind of find ourselves in this situation where when we want to do it at scale, we might we may find it hard to compete with the coupled Harbor Bosch and and electrolyzer design. I don't know what you guys think.

annotations.present new idea: MS introduces the idea of a fundamental concern regarding the engineering perspective of electrochemical nitrogen reduction, contrasting it with the ease of hydrogen generation via electrolysis.

annotations.expand on existing idea: MS expands on the challenges of electrochemical nitrogen reduction at scale, mentioning the need for a triple phase boundary and the difficulty of transporting gaseous species, building upon the previous discussion about the challenges of nitrogen reduction.

annotations.offer constructive criticism: MS offers a critique by highlighting the engineering challenges of electrochemical nitrogen reduction compared to the coupled Haber-Bosch and electrolyzer design, suggesting it may be hard to compete at scale.

annotations.encourage participation: MS encourages participation by asking "I don't know what you guys think.", inviting others to share their perspectives on the topic.

utterance: AT: I might have missed a little bit of that, but so you're saying that because the electrochemical row requires the addition of the proton there, I mean, when I think about that compared to the traditional Harbor Bosch, you do need the net thermodynamic states are going to be the same. So the net driving forces are the same. So are you saying it's an engineering challenge to get them all co-located on the active site?

annotations.ask clarifying question: AT is asking MS to confirm if their argument is that the electrochemical route faces an engineering challenge in co-locating the proton on the active site, compared to the traditional Haber-Bosch process, after admitting they missed part of the explanation.

utterance: MS: A transport.

annotations.explain or define term or concept: MS is likely referring to the transport challenges associated with electrochemical nitrogen reduction, building on his previous statement about the difficulty of bringing gaseous species to the reaction site.

utterance: MS: very the triple phase boundary variant in a classical catalytic environment. We have very good transport between two gases going to an iron-based catalytic site and then turning over to ammonia.

annotations.expand on existing idea: This utterance expands on MS's previously stated concern about the engineering challenges of electrochemical nitrogen reduction, specifically focusing on the transport advantages of the Haber-Bosch process over electrochemical methods, building on the discussion of the difficulties of electrochemical nitrogen reduction compared to the Haber-Bosch process.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: The utterance provides supporting evidence for the engineering challenges of electrochemical nitrogen reduction by highlighting the good transport in a classical catalytic environment with two gases going to an iron-based catalytic site, supporting the idea that the Haber-Bosch process has transport advantages.

utterance: AT: I mean, it's been you could argue that that transport has been fine-tuned over, you know, decades at least for development there of the fluidized bed technology to get there. And I don't know, to me, to me, it sounds like it's not a scientific barrier. It's a technical question of how are we going to do it as opposed to saying, even if we do get it, it won't be efficient.

annotations.expand on existing idea: AT is building on MS's point about the engineering challenges of electrochemical nitrogen reduction, adding that the transport in the Haber-Bosch process has been fine-tuned over decades.
annotations.express alternative decision: AT is disagreeing with MS's implicit suggestion that electrochemical nitrogen reduction is fundamentally limited, arguing that it's a technical challenge, not a scientific barrier, implying that it can be overcome with engineering solutions.

utterance: HW: It's it's I agree with Marshall. It's a big problem, but I also agree with Andrew that it could be solved. Like we can take examples from, let's say, oxygen reduction fuel cell. They also need these type of triple phase boundaries, but they can deliver very high current density, which means that you can also deliver very high production rates per area of your electro, right? But the challenge here now is we don't have platinum as efficient in OOR as iron catalyst. We can we can have for NRR. That's I think will be the critical challenge here to deliver the scale that you mentioned to compete with Harbor Bosch.

annotations.express agreement: HW agrees with Marshall that the triple phase boundary is a big problem for electrochemical nitrogen reduction, acknowledging Marshall's prior concerns about the engineering challenges of bringing reactants together at scale.
annotations.expand on existing idea: HW expands on the discussion about the challenges of electrochemical nitrogen reduction by suggesting that the problem could be solved, drawing an analogy to oxygen reduction fuel cells which also require triple phase boundaries and can deliver high current density.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: HW provides supporting evidence by mentioning oxygen reduction fuel cells as an example of a system with triple phase boundaries that can achieve high current density, suggesting that similar solutions might be possible for nitrogen reduction.
annotations.explain or define term or concept: HW explains the concept of triple phase boundaries by relating it to oxygen reduction fuel cells, clarifying the challenges and potential solutions for electrochemical nitrogen reduction.
annotations.present new idea: HW presents the idea of drawing inspiration from oxygen reduction fuel cells to address the challenges of triple phase boundaries in electrochemical nitrogen reduction, suggesting a new approach to the problem.

utterance: OL: Sorry. I just I just want to add a bit of organic chemist perspective on the matter. I feel like, you know, we're asked to dream big, right? And the topic is beyond CO2 and, you know, come up with the craziest idea we can come up with. And, you know, on one hand, from a from a from a chemistry perspective, the nitrogen molecule doesn't have a dipole, so it's really hard to activate for you at a surface, at a molecule, you name it. But on the other hand, you know, I think that there are from from a synthetic perspective, there are a lot of other products that could be made from a nitrogen reduction process. And so, you know, if that is a way to, you know, frame the question not necessarily in terms of replacing Harbor Bosch, which we know that is difficult, but maybe adding a different kind of value to to to a process. And so something that comes to mind is capturing carbon dioxide, converting it to formaldehyde, then making ammonia electrocatalytically, and there are some systems that do this, and then just adding a cyanide source and making amino acids. You know, these are basic building blocks for organic synthesis and pharmaceutical science. And, you know, these discussions today have really kind of catalyzed these ideas where, you know, maybe we just need to think a little bit bigger, right? And, you know, Harbor Bosch is extraordinarily difficult to make an argument against, but maybe there there are other ways to to frame the problem as an opportunity in a different context.

annotations.present new idea: The speaker suggests a new approach: capturing CO2, converting it to formaldehyde, making ammonia electrocatalytically, adding a cyanide source, and making amino acids, which are building blocks for organic synthesis and pharmaceutical science.

annotations.expand on existing idea: The speaker expands on the discussion about nitrogen reduction by suggesting alternative products and framing the problem as an opportunity in a different context, rather than directly replacing the Haber-Bosch process.

utterance: GS: Those are nice thoughts. Anyone want to follow up on that or brainstorm around that idea?

encourage participation.Explanation: GS encourages other participants to follow up on OL's ideas or brainstorm around them.

utterance: AT: I'll also add to that, there may be some high value pathways. I mean, you mentioned amino acids or proteins or organic molecules. This may be a way of recouping some of the cost that would be required to do this. utterance: CJ: So I want to throw out something about BECCS. I don't know how many folks have talked about thought about that technology. I find it fascinating from an engineering perspective because one of the one of the interesting things about biomass as an energy source or a feedstock for anything is that it's very distributed. If you manage start to think about BECCS as a power source as well as a way to produce negative emissions, you're now talking about very distributed CO2 or carbon storage. So that leads me to thinking about a future landscape that has either a massive amount of CO2 pipelines if we're going to sequester CO2 geologically or a massive reliance on biochar and the associated costs with shipping solids around for sequestration. And so I'm just I'm unsure which of those two is is lower hanging fruit and more likely to be attainable in the short term because both from a systems engineering and logistics perspective seem complex to me. But if you look at climate models, there's always a massive amount of BECCS that's suggested as a solution for our negative emissions challenge. And in principle, the two parts are there, bioenergy and carbon capture and sequestration, but putting them all together into a system seems really challenging to me.

present new idea.Explanation: CJ introduces the topic of BECCS (Bioenergy with Carbon Capture and Storage) and its implications for carbon storage and distribution, which is a new direction in the conversation.

expand on existing idea.Explanation: CJ expands on the idea of negative emissions technologies by discussing the challenges and complexities of implementing BECCS, building upon the previous discussion of carbon sequestration and negative emissions.
